ASTR001 is a general introduction to astronomy intended for non-majors. This course covers most topics relating to astronomy, including celestial bodies, large cosmic structures, the origins and future of the universe, and the possibility of extraterrestrial life. The class requires elementary algebra and geometry, and is not recommended for physical-science majors or Engineering students. It fulfills the College Sector VI: Physical World requirement.

Many reviewers found the subject interesting, although some wrote that the material was presented in a dull manner. A significant number of reviewers noted that the class relied heavily on the mathematics behind astronomy, and they would have liked greater emphasis on concepts over calculations.

Out of thirteen reviewers, four considered Professor Truch “a boring guy.” One wrote that he seemed to show “no interest in the subject material.” They noted that in lecture, the professor would read off the slides which were often “verbatim” reproductions of the textbook. On the other hand, one student thought that Professor Truch handled the material well, and another mentioned that his explanations were “fluid and understandable.”

Most students take ASTR001 to fulfill their Physical World sector requirement. Students had quite varying opinions on the difficulty level of this class. Homework assignments were easy, but time-consuming. Some reviewers liked the exams and thought they were well balanced; others thought they were “slightly too difficult” or “extremely unfair” because they covered a very large breadth of material. There was general agreement that exams could have focused more on concepts over mathematics – one reviewer stated that the class contained much more math than they expected. Some reviewers thought the class was “very easy.” Others felt it was “too much work” for a class that people take to fulfill requirements.

ASTR001 is a general introduction to astronomy intended for non-majors. This course covers most topics relating to astronomy, including celestial bodies, large cosmic structures, the origins and future of the universe, and the possibility of extraterrestrial life. The class requires elementary algebra and geometry, and is not recommended for physical-science majors or Engineering students. It fulfills the College Sector VI: Physical World requirement.

Some reviewers found the subject interesting. One wrote that this class is “great for those looking to take a course just to learn something new.” Others found the class boring and “too science-intensive.” Opinions on the quantitative part of the course were mixed. A few students said that they encountered much more math than expected, but another reviewer said that the material “is presented in a way that is easy for non-quantitatively oriented people to excel in the course.” There was some dissatisfaction with the content of lectures – one reviewer complained that the 1.5-hour lectures consisted only of going over slides which “had content taken directly from the textbook,” leading to a boring lecture experience.

Most reviewers praised Professor Bernardi’s personality, calling her “brilliant,” “enthusiastic,” “available,” “helpful,” and “friendly.” Another felt her grading was “very fair.” One student, however, said she was “difficult to understand.” Most criticism was directed more towards the presentation of lectures than at the professor.

Most students take ASTR001 to fulfill their Physical World sector requirement. One reviewer wrote, “Everyone is there in order to get out of a sector requirement and nobody has a genuine interest in astronomy so it is an awful class.” The twelve reviewers for the course did not speak much to the difficulty level. Some thought there was too much math; others thought there was a good balance for students who are not quantitatively minded. One review consisted of the single phrase: “too much homework.” One student mentioned that homework assignments and tutorials were useful in preparing for exams.
